comments.body: `mutable` answers my previous question about modifying in an accessor.

I guess I would expect this interface to provide just one function, which takes in a fully specified GVK and returns a fully specified GVK. It answers the question "what should this type be converted to?"

The problem is that responsibility today belongs to the scheme, which has the info "what version _may_ this kind be converted to".  This type is "given this info, do you you want to express a preference about _where_ to go".
In that case, maybe the scheme should give a list of options and this interface chooses one.
Why do these need to be separate interfaces? Why not just always re-call the parent converter?

Because you don't always want the same convertor to be used.  For example, the majority of runtime.Unknown -> runtime.RawExtension conversions could be generic to context (just does a straight up decode).  But specific cases actually need to handle objects differently - for instance Templates don't actually want to decode objects because type marshaling would break the template replacement.  Templates want to use the unstructured decoder, which preserves the exact syntax of the owner.

So basically, each top level object can define a distinct behavior.
Seems like this should have `SupportedMediaTypes` too.

Probably at some point, did not expose it yet until we need it.

> - // version decoded, or an error. If into is non-nil, it will be used as the target type and implementations
> - // may choose to use it rather than reallocating an object. However, the object is not guaranteed to be
> - // populated. The returned object type is not guaranteed to match into.
> - Decode(data []byte, defaults *unversioned.GroupVersionKind, into Object) (Object, *unversioned.GroupVersionKind, error)

What is innate typing of the scheme?
Does actual kind, group, and version decoded mean the serialized
kind/group/version in data?

Is it possible to remove `into` and the return value `*unversioned.GroupVersionKind` from the signature? Then this method is pure serialization. It will make the refactoring much more difficult, but it seems to worth the effort.

Into is pretty widely used in our codebase.  It's actually more correct in
some cases than version, because internal clients ultimately need a
concrete struct to deal with, and most decodes end up with a cast.

I'm debating between two approaches to layering conversion and
serialization.  The first, in this pr, wraps a naive serializer (limited
version awareness) with a version aware codec.  The challenge is that the
interface isn't quite identical.  On the plus side, it was possible to
prove that we don't need 6 decode methods in order to satisfy our use
cases, which was something I wasn't sure about until I went and touched all
the code again to remember.  On the negative side, negotiated versions are
harder because a lot of code that has access to a codec may want to choose
the target serialization (specifically RESTMapper used by client commands
and printers).  We also need access in a few cases to the versioned object
and the original (such as in the apply code) but passing two codecs would
be silly

The alternative is an interface like Decode([]byte, DecodeOptions{}), where
DecodeOptions may optionally specify things like:
- version defaulting
- desired target version
- desired target object (into)
- expected (or allowed) serialization formats
- callback to get access to the raw deserialized object
- callback to check the type of the object prior to final conversion, or to
  perform advanced decoding
- callback to transform nested encoded objects (List, Watch, etc)

I may try that interface to see whether it simplifies the code.  Same for
Encoding as well.

Ultimately the decoupling between conversion and serialization is necessary
for sanity of code, even a temporary state along the way is an improvement
- there was lots of accumulated edge cases that deserved to be flensed and
  given proper solutions.

Even with the comment, the utility of this interface isn't clear to me.  Why shouldn't I just check for `Serializer`?  Do we anticipate drift?

Clarify usage.  Serializer is passed to interfaces that expect raw
behavior.  Codec is passed to things that expect conversion.  There are
other factorings in the future, such as having Decode take more options
(like the selected serializer).  I don't want to hang up on that - the
changes I am making to isolate clients from the impact of this makes
Serializer a lower level stratification, not a higher level one.
